crochet the knot pictured above 1 1 gauge absolute gauge isn t important this can be made with large or small hooks the finished piece will be very roughly as wide as 60 single_crochet and as tall as 30 single_crochet relative gauge is important if you make a rectangle of single crochets that is 20 stitches long and 23 row high it should make a square that is its height should pretty much equal its width 1 2 materials hardware in addition to a crochet hook you ll need a tapestry needle and safety pins waste yarn you ll need about a metre of waste yarn for making running stitch markers other you ll need some way to label the stitch markers either masking tape that you can write on directly or scraps of paper and clear tape yardage this is a small piece budget about 70 metres for the main strand and about 10 metres for the outline more precisely but possibly less usefully the strand takes about 2100 stitches which is around 30 times the amount of yarn used in a straight section 6 row of 12 stitches or 5 times the amount of yarn in a 20-by-23 swatch the outline takes about 600 stitches time the exemplar pictured in this pattern took aboout 5 hours to make 1 3 abbreviations chain everything you need to know except exactly how many stitches to put where read this section before you tackle the pattern in section 3 2 2 1 preparing markers we ll be using running stitch markers with labels running stitch markers are just lengths of scrap yarn woven vertically through the row the labels are added by taping on a scrap of paper or writing directly on masking tape or label stickers these stitch markers serve several purposes first while making the strands they serve as double-checks if the marker isn t showing up where it s supposed to one of us made a mistake second if you lose your place they help you find it again third once the knot is finished the labels will help match it up to figure 5 and determine where all the crossings are finally when you re sewing the knot together to finish it
